title: 'Spider-Man No Way Home' Poised for Biggest Box-Office Weekend in the Pandemic; One estimate says the Marvel movie could bring in over $200 million across North America
text:
The movie, "Spider-Man: No Way Home," opened for previews Thursday and is the third with Tom Holland in the lead role as the Marvel comic-book superhero.

Shawn Robbins, chief analyst at movie publication BoxOffice Pro, said there has been pent-up demand for a big movie event to go to. The last one he could think of was the release of "Star Wars: The Rise Of Skywalker" in December 2019.

"Spider-Man is universally appealing," Mr. Robbins said. "There's just a must-see aura around this movie."

Demand is high even amid a rise of Covid-19 cases as the Omicron variant has spread rapidly.

Sony Corp.'s Sony Pictures Entertainment, which is releasing "Spider-Man: No Way Home," tempered expectations and said it expects an opening in the $130 million range, based on the unpredictability of the box office, the performance of past "Spider-Man" movies and how films have fared during the pandemic.

That would still make it the biggest debut of the past two years, surpassing "Venom: Let There Be Carnage," a Spider-Man spinoff from Sony that brought in $90 million during its first weekend in early October, according to box office-tracker Comscore.

BoxOffice Pro expects a much bigger opening weekend for the newest "Spider-Man" than Sony: $224 million. Mr. Robbins said the number is based on social-media chatter, ticket presales and other indicators.

It already earned $50 million from Thursday evening previews, according to Comscore. Mr. Robbins said the preview sales would make Sony's $130 million estimate easy to beat.

Movie-theater-chain operator AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. said 1.1 million people watched "Spider-Man: No Way Home" in its theaters Thursday, the highest number of people watching one movie in a day at AMC during all of 2020 and 2021.

The biggest-ever opening for a Spider-Man movie was 14 years ago, back when Tobey Maguire played the web-slinging superhero in 2007's "Spider-Man 3." That movie brought in $151 million on its opening weekend, according to Comscore.
